repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
1. Potential race initializing it.
2. We can't usefully return a globals dictionary because the coroutine module is shared, and thus we don't actually know which module it comes from.

(picked out of a larger change in the interests of keeping that simple(r))

comment_data.body: I really don't like these unconditional critical sections around one-time initialised variables/fields. We should always be able to read and return the readily initialised value immediately, and only need a critical section to guard the initial setting.

To me, it doesn't sound unreasonable to keep a reference to at least the module globals (or the module itself?) also in the coroutine. We do that for functions, why not for coroutines? In fact, seeing us move more towards sharing type implementations between multiple modules, it seems rather obvious to me that their instances should know where they came from.

Python coroutines don't have a `__module__` attribute (unlike functions) so there isn't an obvious use for it apart from this globals variable.

I think that's why I decided it wasn't worth the effort. But can definitely add it if you think it's a useful thing to provide.

Hmm. This was really the only place where we used `CGLOBAL` in the whole of `Coroutine.c` for anything but type internal (potentially shared) type references. You're probably right that it can just go. Let's keep it like this.

commit.message:
Fix a couple of issues with __Pyx_Coroutine_get_frame

1. Potential race initializing it.
2. We can't usefully return a globals dictionary because
   the coroutine module is shared, and thus we don't actually
   know which module it comes from.
Avoid critical section if we can.

milestone.description:
* Remove code for Python 2 and Python < 3.8.
* Integrate better with Python 3.
* Improve support for the Limited API.
* Start supporting GIL-free Python 3.13.
* Support the Py3.13 `sys.monitoring` API.
* Support and use `am_send` for coroutines.

title: Fix a couple of issues with __Pyx_Coroutine_get_frame
